Review
Chemical, physical, and biological coordination: An interplay between materials and enzymes as potential platforms for immobilization
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ccr.2019.02.024 0010-8545/ 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article history: Received 23 November 2018 Accepted 18 February 2019
Keywords: Coordination Nanostructured materials Enzyme Immobilization Biocatalysis Nanobiocatalyst
Suitable coordination between the new wave of nanostructured materials and catalyst of interests play a critical role in developing nanobiocatalysts with new or improved functionalities. In this context, enzymes with natural origin are versatile biocatalysts with multifunctional characteristics and have been widely utilized in various sectors such as environmental, energy, biomedical, pharmaceutical, cosmeceutical, nutraceutical, fine chemicals, agro-industrial, and food industry, etc. The deployment of enzymes in a non-natural environment has limited boundaries such as the high production cost, challenging separation, purification, and liability to deactivation under non-ambient conditions. These drawbacks can be overcome by the design and fabrication of novel hybrid and functionalized nanobiocatalyst. However, appropriate coordination at chemical, physical, and the biological level is highly requisite to engineer such nanobiocatalysts of supreme interests. Currently, the generation and development of diverse nanomaterials along with new strategies have been established from the nanotechnology perspectives, where the integration of naturally occurring biocatalysts with suitable nanomaterials offer an exceptional corridor to upgrade the catalytic performances of pristine enzymes. Recent innovations in nanobiotechnology furnished numerous opportunities to integrate natural biocatalysts to a range of nanostructured materials with unique attributes. These newly introduced nanomaterials show/impart additional characteristics which enzyme in their pristine form fails to demonstrate on their own. Manipulation of these nanomaterials for enzyme delivery or recovery, remote access for activation or deactivation of enzymatic activity, and new catalytic entities with harmonizing functionalities has taken this field to a new horizon with pronounced biotechnological applications in the coming years. The present review emphases on the recent developments along with the exploitation of nanostructured materials including nanofibers, hybrid nanoflowers, mesoporous/nanoporous carriers, carbon nanotubes, magnetic or non-magnetic nanoparticles, and nanocomposites as support carriers for the immobilization of different enzymes to develop nanobiocatalysts with potential activity and stability characteristics. In addition, strategies for the synthesis and various types of new functionalization approaches, particularly the chemical method for its capability to modify nanomaterials with enormous functionalities are discussed. Towards the end, challenges related to the use of nanobiocatalysts and their possible solution are summarized.

1. Introduction
In biotechnology, spectacular advances and breakthroughs have witnessed an accelerating curiosity in the development of safer, highly efficient, overall cost-effective, green in the process, scalable and sustainable modalities and bioprocesses using enzymes. Exceptional characteristics such as catalytic activity, selectivity and specificity furnish enzymes as intriguing (bio)catalysts for many applications including biocatalysis, environmental remediation, biomedicine, biosensors development, agrochemical, and food industry [95,8,1]. Biocatalysts encourage environmental ‘‘green” and more efficient bioprocesses because of low chemical utilization and lack of generating any toxic by-products during the reaction. Nevertheless, the use of free enzymes implicates several obstacles such as high enzyme costs, enzyme deactivation by solvents, instability, and efficient recovery from reaction media, as well as scale-up barriers that can be partially overcome using carrier immobilized/insolubilized enzymes [17,89]. Insolubilized enzyme derivatives have improved operational characteristics under harsh conditions such as highly acidic/basic pH environment, extreme thermal conditions, or the presence of organic solvents, etc. [53]. Enhanced product quality and lower processing cost are the additional benefits of the immobilized forms of the enzymes [21]. Enzyme immobilization using insoluble support matrices is advantageous for practical applications due to convenience in handling, ease separation of enzymes from a reaction mixture, higher stability and reusability, prevention of interactions with interfaces, rigidification via multipoint covalent attachment, prevention of subunit dissociation, improved activity, selectivity, specificity, resistance to inhibitions, and even an improved purity [120,136,12,128,135,137,20,134].
The development of immobilization techniques combined with several different support matrices based on either natural or synthetic materials has been widely examined in recent studies [127,18,14,20]. Nonetheless, following immobilization, the deployment of immobilized-enzyme based bio-catalytic reactor system may lead to an increase in the overall enzyme performance because of the alteration and disrupting enzyme-carrier interaction [152]. Even under different reaction conditions, optimal immobilization protocol stimulates and preserve the hyperactivity and enzyme stability, respectively [120]. Therefore, it is of pivotal significance to scrutinize enzyme carriers with robust, biocompatible, and recoverable attributes [149]. Moreover, the limitations above can be addressed using a range of novel nanostructured
materials as carrier support for enzymes [65,80,1,19,140]. Several unique attributes such as efficient enzyme loading, high specific surface area, and pronounced biocatalytic potential render nano supports as ideal candidates for commercial-scale biocatalysis in aqueous/nonaqueous media [36,1,20]. The nanobiocatalyst is explicitly an engineered nanocarrier–enzyme association, which displays remarkable advantages in terms of improved biocatalytic performance and steadiness. Use of nanostructured materials allows the construction of a biocompatible microenvironment surrounding the enzyme molecule for optimal reaction proficiencies. Multiple recycling abilities accompanied by facile separation of nanostructured carriers, in particular, magnetic nanocomposites support can considerably trim-down the overall cost of enzymebased bioprocesses in an industrial setting [159,57]. To date, a large number of functionalized nanostructured materials including nanofibers, organic-inorganic hybrid nanoflowers, mesoporous/nanoporous carriers, carbon nanotubes, magnetic or nonmagnetic nanoparticles, nanocomposites, nanocontainers, and nanosheets have been endeavored as support carriers to develop nanobiocatalyst. The driving force for synthesizing novel nanostructured carriers with distinct structures and properties arises from the growing biotechnological interest of nanobiocatalysts, and the application of such advanced nanocarriers can potentially augment the enzymes potentialities.
In the last decade, various binding strategies have been attempted to develop novel biocatalytic system-based modalities at nano-level. Among these, the covalent coupling is advocated as the most reliable immobilization approach for evading leaching of enzymes [143]. However, the enzyme leaching issues have largely challenged the simplicity of various, in practice, physical adsorption-based methods and their facile implementation at large-scale [50]. Notably, immobilization methods vary based on the physicochemical properties of both nanostructured carriers, and enzymes, along with their interfacial interactions subject to their respective biochemical and bioengineering applications. Considering the above background, herein, we emphases on the recent developments along with the exploitation of nanostructured materials as novel support carriers for the immobilization of different enzymes to develop nanobiocatalysts. First, we discussed the unique structure, physicochemical properties and notable advantages of nanomaterials as enzyme immobilization platforms. The synthesis and various types of new functionalization strategies, particularly the chemical method for its multiplicity and capability to modify nanomaterials with enormous functionalities are

highlighted. Then we comprehensively deliberated the unique physicochemical properties along with the advancements of upto-date nanomaterials such as nanofibers, mesoporous/nanoporous carriers, carbon nanotubes, magnetic or nonmagnetic nanoparticles, and nanocomposites as support nanocarriers to develop nanobiocatalysts with suitable examples.
2. Advantages/disadvantages of nanomaterials as immobilization platforms
Advantageous features of nanostructured materials such as available functional entities e.g., amino, thiol, carboxylic, hydroxyl, and epoxy groups, high surface area to volume ratios, insolubility during reaction, facile recovery and reusability, high affinity to enzymes and higher enzyme loading furnish nano supports potentially suitable host candidates for enzyme immobilization (Fig. 1) [61,21,20]. Besides the advantages mentioned above, there are some disadvantages and limitations that should be considered with care. Fig. 2 illustrates technical limitations (blue circles) of nanomaterials and potential strategies to functionalize to overcome potential limitations and impart new functional entities with specific examples. The number of nanomaterials-coupled enzyme molecules can be easily assessed depending on the physical properties of biomolecules and the carrier support. In contrast to macroscale matrices, the low mass transfer resistance of nano supports-coupled biocatalysts further augments the enzymatic activity [72]. Owing to the ease of handling and operational procedures, the use of nanomaterials as matrices support superior flexibility in the reactor system [124]. Recently, Huang et al. [57] developed a novel biocompatible magnetic chitin nanofiber composite (MCNC) as a support for enzyme immobilization using
chymotrypsin (CT) as a model enzyme. Easy separation and recovery of magnetic nanoparticles for recycling using an external magnetic field circumvents the use of high-speed centrifugation separation purposes. This, in turn, reduces the overall processing cost of enzymes immobilized on nano-supports with magnetic functionalities, therefore substantially enhance the functional stability along with continuous recycling/reusability of such immobilized enzymes [168]. However, prior to the intended applications of immobilized enzymes in biotechnological sectors, it is of worth significance to pursue the potential merits and demerits of nanobased support matrices. In this perspective, the preparatory aspects such as preprocessing, synthesis procedures, surface modification (in specific cases), controlled dispersivity (an empirical property that determines the characteristic dispersion), and dynamic stability or shelf life or nano-based support matrices renders some specific but technical challenges [77]. For instance, some processes necessitate certain reaction conditions such as controlled pH and temperature environment to avoid precipitation and aggregation of reaction components. The stabilization of such types of nanomaterials against aggregation can be accomplished by a polymer shell coating of the nanomaterial owing to the large decline of their surface energy than pristine nanomaterial [122]. In addition, the direct handling of materials with considerable toxicity also pose health-related issues and environmental hazards, for example, carbon nanotubes in their pure powder form have toxic effects [6,22]. There is a dire need to develop a toxicity analysis procedure for specific nanomaterial for safety measures prior to using nano supports. Moreover, monitoring of nanomaterial impact on the surroundings and detection of exposure level in fabrication is also highly crucial. A comprehensive understanding of nanomaterials interaction with proteins is essential prior to
enzyme immobilization platforms.

developing a sustainable product of interest. Following careful consideration of the points mentioned above, the industrial and academic sectors along with regulatory bodies, legislative authorities and policymakers should elucidate nanomaterials benefits and risk to maximizing their large-scale exploitation without conceding the public health and environmental integrity.
3. Synthesis of nanostructures and nanomaterials
Nano-size materials having at least one of the dimensions with 1–100 nm is known as nanoscience. They include zerodimensional (nanocrystals), one-dimensional (nanotubes and nanowires) and two-dimensional (nanowalls and nanofilms). The properties of nanostructured materials typically depend on size, synthetic route, and shape [118], and can be synthesized through physical and chemical approaches. Nevertheless, chemical methods are more effective due to their more control over the shape, properties, and functionalization of nanomaterials. Though some chemical strategies and reagents have been used with a wide range of reaction conditions, some simple and useful synthetic techniques of nanomaterials are presented in this section.
The nanoscale products can be synthesized through bottom-up or top-down based fabrication methods. Top-down fabrication is primarily used in the microelectronics industry, where small features can be created on a large surface through lithographic methods. The type of lithography method affects the size of nanomaterials. Whereas, bottom-up fabrication is relevant to the industry, where small molecules or atoms assembled into a large building block of up to 100 nm size. More specifically, the route of synthesis mainly depends on the acquired shape of nanomaterials. For example, numerous chemical-based methods such as solvothermal, decomposition of molecular precursor and reduction of salts, etc. can be used to engineer or develop a zero-dimensional
material. Metals nanocrystals generally synthesized by reduction of salts and metal oxide through the decomposition of precursor compounds such as cupferronates, metal acetate, and acetylacetonates under solvothermal conditions. The nanoparticles with a core of metal, semiconductor or oxide nanocrystals and shells composed of different materials are known as core@shell materials. These materials are generated through the decomposition of salt, precursor addition, and UV-photo activation technique. Nanowires are another important class of nanomaterials, which can be prepared through vapor phase methods, include oxide-assisted growth, vapor-liquid-solid growth, use of carbothermal reactions and vapor-solid growth. These one-dimensional nanowires can also be synthesized through solution methods such as oriented attachment, seed-assisted growth, and polyol method. Similarly, the development of inorganic materials such as fullerenes and nanotubes of different materials can be prepared through arcdischarge, a plasma-enhanced laser deposition technique, thermally induced exfoliation, electrochemical deposition, radio frequency magnetron-sputtering technique, electrochemical etching, and laser ablation. In order to synthesize two-dimensional nanocrystalline films and nanowalls, liquid-liquid interface exfoliation method and thermal exfoliation are used, respectively. The synthesis at nanoscience is not limited and varies with the shape of nanomaterials. However, there are some common methodologies, which are mostly used for the synthesis of a different type of nanomaterials as explained below.
3.1. Template-based method
A variety of nano and micro materials can be synthesized using a template-based method which is father categorized as (1) softtemplate, and (2) hard-template methods. In a template-based method, nanomaterials are synthesized within the pores of the porous membrane. In most of the cases, these porous membranes

contain cylindrical pores that are useful for the synthesis of cylindrical or tabular nanomaterials [60]. The final phase of these material depends on the chemistry of pores wall and properties of materials obtained. Notably, this method is intensively used for the fabrication of nanofibers and nanotubes grafted with semiconductors, carbon, metals and conducting polymers [93,59]. Both above-mentioned template-based categories, i.e., (1) softtemplate, and (2) hard-template methods have been exploited to engineer silver-based nanostructures, e.g., silver nanowires (AgNWs) ranging 10–200 nm in diameter and 5–100 mm in lengths [171,9]. Based on literature evidence, almost any type of solid matter can be engineered within nanoporous templates subject to a suitable chemical and reaction environment. Around five representative strategies, i.e., (1) electrochemical deposition (2) electroless (i.e., chemical) deposition (3) chemical polymerization (4) sol-gel deposition and (5) chemical vapor deposition (CVD) that can, in principle, be used to synthesize template-based nanostructures [60,59].
Wirtz and Martin [158] prepared gold nanowires and nanotubes via electroless deposition of Au onto the pore walls of a commercially available nanoporous polycarbonate filter with cylindrical nanoscopic pores. The pores in the polycarbonate filter (support membrane) act as a template for the nanostructures. Very recently, Liu et al. [87] developed hollow, and porous nickel sulfide (NiS) nanocubes starting from Ni–Co Prussian blue analogue nanocubes as the template. As developed NiS nanocubes showed as an efficient enzyme (peroxidase) mimic for colorimetric detection of hydrogen peroxide by catalyzing the oxidization of 3,30,5,50-tetra methylbenzidine. The catalytic oxidation followed Michaelis–Menten kinetics and showed a ping-pong mechanism of enzyme action. The findings were used to develop a rapid, sensitive, and selective colorimetric H2O2 assay with a response that is linear in the 4– 40 lM range with a detection limit of 1.72 lM (signal-to-noise ratio of 3) [87].
3.2. Sonochemical synthesis
Sonochemistry is the emerging research area in which molecules undergo a chemical reaction powered by high-frequency ultrasound radiation ranging from 20 kHz to 10 MHz [147]. Sonochemistry can be categorized as (1) primary sonochemistry and (2) secondary sonochemistry. Among them, the first one deals with the gas-phase chemistry occurring inside collapsing bubbles, whereas, the secondary sonochemistry mainly deals with solution-phase chemistry occurring outside the bubbles [163]. In sonochemical-based synthesis, several phenomena are responsible for the production and modification of nanomaterials subject to the ultrasonic irradiation. The main event in sonochemistry is the creation, growth, and collapse of a bubble that is formed in the liquid that facilitates 20 kHz sonic radiation to break the chemical bonds [148]. However, this last stage ‘‘collapse” occurs within just less than a nanosecond [54,11], along with very high cooling rates and more than 1011 K/s are obtained [148].
Various organometallic materials, industrial manufacturing process, and organic syntheses are carried out using highintensity ultrasound [133,131]. As the ultrasound can generate temperature more than 5000 K and pressure exceeding to 1000 atm, that leads to the origin of sonochemistry in the field of science [146]. This ultrasound can dissociate the bonds of organometallic compounds and generate free metals due to their high-temperature generation during bubble collapse. These free metals can be used to synthesize the nanoparticle or nanostructured materials through injection into liquid phase and nucleation. Sonochemical synthesis is useful only for those solution having an appropriate template or stabilizers. In this prospect, two kinds of ultrasound sources can be used including ultrasound horns and
M .Bilal,H .M .N .Iqbal/Coordination Chem istry R eview s 388 (2019) 1– 23 7
8 M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23
an ultrasound bath. More commonly, the ultrasonic bath is used by many researchers for physical effects such as generating emulsion, facilitating crystallization, activating surface, accelerating dissolution of solids and exfoliating layered materials [10].
Recently, Okoli et al. [102] reported a sonochemical synthesis of small-sized (3 nm ± 0.05 nm) bimetallic metal-alloy nanoparticles and their potential use as electrocatalysts. The study reports on the synthesis of molybdenum-palladium alloy nanomaterials supported on functionalized carbon material in various solvents, i.e., hexadecane, ethanol, ethylene glycol, polyethylene glycol (PEG 400) and Ionic liquids (ILs). Following characterization, the TEM images and the XRD pattern of synthesized Pd3Mo showed that particle sizes did not increase in 30–60 min of sonication at 40 C, and the size of Pd3Mo/C or Pd3Mo/MWCNT was limited to 2.7–3.0 nm due to the geometric constraints of the MWCNT diameter and stabilization in ILs [102]. From the electrocatalytic viewpoint, Selvarajan et al. [129] used a simple sonochemical approach to fabricate a urea biosensor based on zinc phthalocyanine/graphene oxide/urease bioelectrode. The urease immobilized enzyme-based bioelectrode exhibits notable sensing characteristics such as linearity of 0.4–22 mM, the lower detection limit of 0.034 mM, the response time of 10 s and sensitivity of 44.53 lA mM 1 [129].
3.3. Combustion synthesis
The combustion-based synthesis, sometimes also termed as self-propagating high-temperature synthesis (SHS), is highly effective, energy and time saving and low-cost method to produce various industrially relevant nanomaterials [7], such as nanocarriers and nanocarriers-immobilized enzymes, etc. In this process, an internal electromagnetic field generated and can be affected through an external electromagnetic field [43]. The combustion process can be classified as:
(1) Conventional or condensed phase combustion (solid state reactants are used initially) (2) Solution combustion synthesis (SCS) (an aqueous solution used initially) (3) Flame synthesis of nanoparticles (gas-phase combustion)
All three methods based on the same working principle with different starting material phase. For example, in conventional or condensed phase combustion synthesis, the typical heterogeneity scale for the initial solid reactants ranged from 10 to 100 lm and additionally coupled with high reaction temperature range, i.e., >2000 K. However, these high range specificities make it difficult to synthesize nanosize structures with high surface area [7]. As compared to conventional or condensed phase combustion synthesis, the second category, i.e., (SCS) is more versatile and rapid, which allows effective synthesis of a variety of nanosize materials under controlled reaction conditions. Whereas, gas-phase combustion is not directly related to combustion synthesis and produce non-agglomerated fine particles. Similarly, a very short number of nanomaterials can be synthesized by this method with high cost and low effectiveness of the final product [145,121]. In recent years, several notable breakthroughs in the field of combustionbased synthesis or SHS have been reported. For instance, the development of new/improved catalysts and nanocarriers with novel characteristics and functionalities better than their traditional counterparts [107,7]. Several types of nanoporous and nano-sized support matrices have been developed, though using different combinational approaches, which offer a large external surface area along with other requisite features for enzyme immobilization purposes. The nano-sized materials also eliminate the internal diffusion of a substrate and in this way improve the activity of the
immobilized enzyme [172]. Recently, we have reviewed magnetic-based nanoparticles (MNPs) as versatile carriers for enzymes immobilization [21]. Enzyme immobilization on various MNPs forms such as silica-coated MNPs, organic polymermodified MNPs, mesoporous material-modified MNPs metalorganic frameworks (MOFs)-based MNPs has been discussed with suitable examples [21,16]. Catalytic behavior of carbonic anhydrase enzyme immobilized onto nonporous silica nanoparticles for enhancing CO2 absorption into a carbonate solution has been reported by Zhang et al. [172]. The results revealed that the activities of the immobilized enzymes were three times higher than that of the free enzyme at 50 C and pH 10.5. Comparative to the free enzyme form, the thermal stability and half-life of the immobilized enzyme were increased up to 4.4 times over a 30-day at 50 C [172].
3.4. Electrospinning synthesis
Electrospinning is a fiber production method which is based on the electric force to draw charged threads of polymers or polymerbased solutions that leads to the formation of uniform fibers with nanometer-scale diameters [81]. It is one of the most versatile technique to synthesize one-dimensional nanomaterials, such as nanofibers, and nanorods, etc. [75,141]. It is based on the principle to reduce the diameter of the viscoelastic jet with electrostatic repulsion between surface charges. The easiness in the synthesis of nanofibers with Jace to volume ratio enhanced the importance of the electrospinning method. With current key advancements in the nanotechnology, electrospinning process has been subcategorized and reported as (1) emulsion electrospinning, (2) melt electrospinning, and (3) coaxial electrospinning. Unlike other methods, electrospinning-based synthesis does not require the use of coagulation chemistry or high temperatures to produce solid threads from polymer melts or solutions. Moreover, it also ensures that no solvent can be carried over into the final product od interests. However, several parameters such as (1) solution properties, e.g., viscosity, conductivity and surface tension, (2) molecularweight and/or molecular-weight distribution and architecture of the polymer, i.e., branched, linear etc. (3) electric potential, (4) flow rate, (5) ambient parameters, i.e., temperature, humidity and air velocity in the chamber, (6) needle gauge, (7) collector type, (8) distance between the sample capillary and collector (9) voltage consistency (10) pump and consistency in the pressure exerted on the sample holder, etc. should be considered with care to engineer fine-tuned constructs of interests. Very recently, Aldhahri et al. [3] reported a facile immobilization of enzyme via coelectrospinning to enhance enzyme reusability and to monitor an activity-based organic semiconductor.
In an earlier study, Jia et al. [67] prepared enzyme-carrying polymeric nanofibers via electrospinning using bioactive polystyrene (PS) with a typical diameter of 120 nm. The results revealed that the apparent hydrolytic activity of the enzyme (achymotrypsin) carrying polymeric nanofibers was over 65% than that of the native enzyme [67]. Immobilization of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) on electrospun Fe3O4/polyacrylonitrile (PAN) magnetic nanofibers (MNFs) for phenol removal has been recently reported [83]. The average diameter of MNFs was about 200– 400 nm along with 19.03 emu/g of maximum saturation magnetic induction. The MNFs-immobilized HRP displayed higher catalytic activity as compared to the free HRP [83].
4. Strategies for nanomaterials’ functionalization
Surface functionalization involving the grafting of desirable functional groups onto the surface of nanomaterials is an impor-
M .Bilal,H .M .N .Iqbal/Coordination Chem istry R eview s 388 (2019) 1– 23 9
10 M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23
tant step to improve/induce the functionality of nanostructured materials [153]. The surface amendment can significantly modify the catalytic performance of the nanomaterials-insolubilized biocatalysts by affecting their dispersion ability and interfaces with enzyme molecules [108]. In addition, surface modification is used to provide biocompatibility, steadiness, and functionality to nanomaterials for their applications. At present, several physical and chemical functionalization strategies are used to decorate nanomaterials surface by numerous organic and inorganic materials such as silica, natural biopolymers, i.e., chitosan, dextran, gelatin, starch, and synthetic polymers [68,1]. Among these methods, the chemical method is simple and common, and eliminate the agglomeration of nanomaterials during functionalization. Chemical functionalization known as covalent functionalization is further divided into different categories explained below. The presence of functional groups on the nanomaterials surface play key roles in enzyme immobilization such as controlling electrostatic interaction with the immobilized enzyme by changing the surface charge of nanosupport and reduce the diameter to facilitate the enzyme encapsulation in nanochannels of the support carrier [79,20].
Earlier, Barbosa et al. [13] developed tailor-made heterofunctional supports as an opportunity in tuning enzyme properties via immobilization. Such type of novel hetero-functional support offers their functional or functionalized entities available at the surface to interact with a target protein during immobilization. In this context, a comprehensive discussion is given on the use of hetero-functional supports to achieve the immobilization and stabilization of target proteins [13,12,17]. For enzyme immobilization via multipoint covalent attachment, divinylsulfone (DVS) activated supports have been established [127]. Based on the surface available functional or functionalized entities, Santos et al. [127] prepared DVS-activated support to immobilize and stabilize enzymes via multipoint covalent attachment. The DVS functional groups are very stable with notable potentialities to react with other available functional groups including primary and secondary amino groups along with hydroxyl, imidazole or thiol groups [12,127,17]. This high reactivity potential thus permits the longterm immobilization and makes DVS-based supports novel candidates to produce a rapid and intense multipoint covalent attachment of enzymes [127,20].
4.1. Direct functionalization
The surface functionalization of nanocomposite materials by the ligand compound is accomplished during the nanomaterial’s fabrication process. The nature of ligand is bi-functional, and one of the functionalities is used to associate ligand with the nano support surface, whereas the other one contains the needed active functionality (modifying group) [142]. This strategy exhibits the advantages of the homogeneous surface coverage in one-pot synthesis, better control over the amount of incorporating ligand in the nanomaterial, and the prospect of using a broad range of functional groups. However, the modifying moieties may not be fully compatible with the fabrication bioprocess as the functionalizing group may react directly with the surface of nanomaterial [100].
4.2. Post-synthetic functionalization (Grafting)
This method is employed for introducing a variety of functional moieties after the preparation of nanomaterials, i.e., attachment of ligand after synthesis of nanomaterials. This bifunctional compound formation first involved the attachment binding of a covalently active binding agent, and then the coupling site is converted into the required functional group. In this method, the nature of functionalizing nanomaterials may not be compatible with the solvent used due to controlled size and dispersion. For the most efficient and effective post-functionalization, a molecule with structure N-C-F (nanoparticle chelating) should be grafted on the surface. For example, mesoporous silica is efficient support for grafting the desired functional group through silylation [111] owing to its easiness to synthesize inorganic-organic hybrid nanocomposite using these functionalized silica nanoparticles. Further, this silanol group can be replaced by a target organic ligand through a single step or multistep attachment. This method is used in many directions including oxide systems and chalcogenides. On the other hand, cluster formation of the functional group and formation of an isolated cluster are the major drawbacks of this procedure, which should be eliminated before further investigation [112,47].
4.3. Polymers in functionalization
Surface polymerization tools play an important role in improving or enhancing the stability and interfacial interactions of nanomaterials. It is also noteworthy to develop highly dispersed multifunctional nanomaterials by polymer grafting. This method
M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23 11
imparts the properties of macromolecules to the nanomaterials surfaces and makes an excellent replacement material for small molecules ligands. For instance, grafting of polyethylene glycol polymers on nanoparticles facilitate the targeting towards tumor tissue, enhance their probability of permeation into tumor tissue, provide resistance toward adsorption of blood serum proteins and enhance their circulation time [101,110,109]. Though polymer functionalization generates macromolecules properties on nanomaterials, it retains the fundamental properties of nanomaterials. Similarly, polymers grafted nanomaterials enhance the controlled release of drugs into the attacked species. For example, temperature responsive poly (N-isopropylacrylamide) (pNIPAAm), functionalized gold nanocages are found to be very effective in this prospect [167,154]. Three key approaches have been attempted for the fabrication of polymer-grafted nanomaterials are described in this section.
4.3.1. Polymer functionalization by ‘Grafting To’ method A number of polymer chains possessing active functionalities as an end group or on their backbone can be synthesized by ‘‘Grafting To” polymer functionalization approach. These active moieties can be readily attracted toward the surface of nanomaterials and
known as grafting to polymer functionalization of nanomaterials. This is a two-steps reaction method, where, the first step involves the synthesis of nanocarriers such as polymer nanowires, membranes, cryogels, mesoporous silica, metal nanoparticles, and chitosan microspheres [115,174]. While the second step involved the attachment of polymers chain having active functionalities. However, this method can lead to reduced grafting densities due to the steric hindrance of polymer crowding already attached to nanomaterials [123].
4.3.2. Polymer functionalization by ‘Grafting From’ method As discussed above, a number of functionalities can be generated on the surface of the nanomaterials, which can be further employed for polymer grafting. A large number of polymers can be directly polymerized on the surface of nanomaterials, such as, if nanomaterials contain a hydroxyl group, we can graft polycaprolactone through ring opening polymerization, and this kind of techniques are known as polymer functionalization by ‘‘Grafting From” method [51]. In this technique, polymerization can be initiated on the surface of nanomaterials using small monomers of the required polymer. It also permits greater control over grafting densities, the thickness of grafted polymer and the functionalities. More
12 M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23
importantly, the small monomers used in this method are not suffering from steric hindrance and easily attached to previously grafted polymer chain [31].
4.3.3. Polymer functionalization by ‘Grafting Through’ method This type of grafting is based on the copolymerization of the already polymerizable group on nanomaterials and targeted polymers free monomer. This technique results in direct polymerization on nanomaterials surface and is mostly employed to nanomaterials necessitating multiple properties [97]. Generally, three types of properties can easily be established in these materials belonging to the nanomaterial, the polymerizable group present on nanomaterials and the targeted polymer [32,96].
5. Nanostructured materials to develop nanobiocatalysts
Nanobiocatalysts implicates the integration of enzyme entity with a nanocarrier as a support material with exceptional optical, electronic, magnetic and external-stimuli-responsive properties. Ove the years, diverse technologies have been attempted for the development of specific and recyclable biocatalysts, such as recombinant DNA technology to trim down the production cost of commercial enzymes and directed evolution for upgrading particular attributes including wider substrate specificity, and bioprocesses
to generate durable and recoverable enzymes for biotechnological applications.
The fabrication and development of novel nanocarriers with inimitable properties and functions comprise:
(i) Construction of unique structures with the increased specific surface area, enabling efficient enzymes confining inside nanostructured cages, substrate diffusion, or nanocarriers recyclability
(ii) Incorporation of other functional entities on the nano-carrier surface to enhance and/or improve the catalytic functionalities of enzymes
(iii) Improve the stabilization including mechanical or thermal stability of nanostructured carriers
In the recent studies, a wide range of advanced nano supports such as nanoparticles, nanofibers, nanotubes, and nanosheets/films have been reported that play a noteworthy contribution in improving the catalytic activity, stability, and functionality of immobilized enzymes. Herein, only up-to-date scientific progress towards fabricating novel nanostructured/nanoporous carriers, i.e., nanofibers, mesoporous/nanoporous carriers, and nanoparticles (magnetic and non-magnetic) with their unique physicochemical structures and properties, for the development of nanobiocatalysts is presented.
M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23 13
5.1. Nanofibers as support to develop nanobiocatalyst
Among the nanomaterials scrutinized for nanobiocatalyst assembly, nanofibers offer many unique features including elevated enzyme binding and homogeneous dispersion. In addition, the interconnectivity along with higher porosity, both, provide nanofibers with low mass transfer resistance. Such key features and self-assembling performances of nanofibers furnish potentialities to develop nanobiocatalyst for bioreactor systems-based bioprocessing applications. One-dimensional nanofibers network has been demonstrated as promising nano supports for enhancing the catalytic performance of biocatalysts owing to their unique traits of high loading capacity, efficiency, and surface area to mass ratio, mass transfer hindrance, and re-processability. Electrospinning, among several other reported methods such as melt blowing, drawing, self-assembly, template synthesis, phase-separation, and force spinning, etc., is considered a typical and widely used technique to generate nanofibers of various sizes ranging from nanometers to a few micrometers [62,99,85,106]. Apart from the single fiber configuration, electrospinning can also produce hybrid nanofibers [41]. Nanofibers can be modified or employed in pristine form to minimize protein denaturation and loss of enzyme activity [157]. Indeed, enzymes can be immobilized to nanofibers-based support material via surface adsorption, entrapment or covalent coupling techniques [33]. Recently, Çakıroğlu
and coworkers [24] prepared a novel polyacrylic acid-based nanofiber membrane via electrospinning technique for covalent immobilization of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) from Electrophorus electricus. The nanofiber membrane-immobilized AChE demonstrated a lower affinity to acetylthiocholine iodide, and the Michaelis-Menten constant of the free and immobilized enzyme was recorded to be 0.4733 and 0.5008 mM, respectively. It showed encouraging recyclability and retained about 87% of its original catalytic activity after ten repeated assay batches. In addition, the membrane-insolubilized biocatalyst preserved almost 70% of the initial activity after storage for two months, whereas the free enzyme completely lost its activity under the identical conditions. Lysozyme was immobilized utilizing bacterial cellulose nanofibers (BCNF) as carrier support by physical absorption approach to investigate its antimicrobial activity and other catalytic properties. The immobilized enzyme showed its pH and temperature optima at 7.0 and 45 C, respectively. Kinetic parameters of Km and Vmax values of 31.18 mg/mL and 112.35 DOD/min, respectively. Storage stability, as well as reusability, was substantially enhanced and the BCNF-adsorbed enzyme presented more than 70% of its preliminary activity after successively reusing for nine times. Finally, the good antimicrobial potential of immobilized lysozyme against a broad range of microorganisms including Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus niger, Listeria monocytogenes, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and Yersinia enterocolitis indicates BCNF as a
14 M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23
suitable support for lysozyme immobilization [14]. Poly (vinyl alcohol) and polyacrylamide bicomponent (PVA–PAAm) nanofibers synthesized by the electrospinning technique method were utilized as a bolster carrier support for covalent attachment of plant-based horseradish peroxidase (HRP) enzyme. Characterization profile by TGA and DSC analyses revealed that the nanofibers were more durable than their counterpart PVA and PAAm polymers. The resulting PVA-PAAm-immobilized HRP demonstrated better thermal and storage stability as compared to its free form of the enzyme. It showed excellent repeated use potential and retained 54% of the initial activity after 25 continuous cycles. Nearly 29.68% phenol removal efficiency of the immobilized HRP at 3 h in real wastewater samples reveal PVA-PAAm nanofiber as an ideal candidate in the degradation and transformation of organic contaminants in industrial wastewater effluents [149]. Liu and coworkers [89,90] developed, for the first time, a biocompatible feather polypeptide and reactive epoxy groups containing novel poly (glycidyl methacrylate-co-methyl acrylate)/feather polypeptide (P(GMA-co-MA)/FP) nano-fibrous membrane and employed for the covalent attachment of lipase enzyme from Candida Antarctica. The resulting biocatalytic system revealed a wider pH and high-temperature resistance, as well as, good reusability and organic solvent stability. At 70 C for three h, the P(GMA-coMA)/FP-immobilized showed about 38% relative activity. It also retained 62% and 75% of its original activity after reuses seven times and treatment in methanol for 12 h, respectively. Soni et al. [140] carried out the immobilization of lipase from Burkholderia cepacia on the surface of carbon nanofibers by adsorption as well as covalent coupling and compared their efficiency to develop nanobiocatalyst. In contrast to covalent binding by 1-ethyl-3-[3dimethylaminopropyl] carbodiimide (EDC)/N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS), which exhibited an immobilization efficiency of 56%, simple adsorption of lipase on carbon nanofibers was observed to be a poor strategy presenting only 36% immobilization efficiency. Table 1 portrays a list of recent studies that have reported the use of various kinds of novel nanofibers as support materials to develop nanobiocatalysts. It can be clearly seen that the immobilized nanobioconjugates displayed higher pH, storage and thermal stability than that of their respective free counterparts.
5.2. Mesoporous/nanoporous carriers as support materials
The fabrication of mesoporous silica and carbon-based materials with tunable nanostructures and uniform nanopores are considered promising support materials for both types of molecules, i.e., small or large [88,45]. The mesoporous/nanoporous structures offer a high surface area and profound enzymes entrapment ability within the pores providing a more biocompatible microenvironment as compared to a planar surface. It has been reported in earlier in the literature that a proper pore size of the porous supports plays a key role to determine the final functionality of the immobilized enzymes and Redox cofactor [38,45]. Thus, as compared to other immobilization methods, it is reported that pore sizes are imperative for enzyme immobilization purposes. Moreover, the enzyme demonstrates greater functionality when the pore diameter of the nanocarrier is comparable to the hydrodynamic size of the biocatalysts. This is because the enzyme retains their original catalytic activity, and consequently, enzymes catalytic site can accelerate interfacial interactions with their corresponding substrate molecules. Under certain conditions, enzyme-support interactions are established, if the enzyme interacts with the support in a higher percentage, which is overall good for enzyme stability. Whereas, the smaller pore size of nanocarriers than that of the catalysts, results in low loading yield. In this context, it is difficult to stabilize the larger proteins [45], owing to the smaller pore size of the support. On the other hand, nanocarriers with pore diameters
greater than the biocatalysts may diminish the enzyme’s performance presumably due to the enzyme leaching or reduced enzyme stability [63,126]. The specific area of these supports largely relies on the particle diameter, thus the pore size or the size of the support particle needs to be measured in the nanometric scale to permit a reasonable enzyme loading capacity [45].
Mesoporous support carriers provide a uniform nanopore system, and these materials can be surfaces modified for effective attachment of enzyme. Several different techniques have been used to develop various kinds of mesoporous materials such as MCM-41, SBA-15, MCF [86,103,98], and these support materials can be engineered to accomplish requisite immobilization requirements. Depending on the support material used, the immobilization approach is also important and play a key role in achieving the higher loading yield and capacity. Among the different immobilization methods including adsorption, entrapment, crosslinking, and covalent binding, surface adsorption, in some instances, may be a superior technique than covalent bonding. In contrary, immobilization by adsorption exhibited the relatively higher enzymatic activity. In previous reports, mesoporous silica material with a huge surface area and highly ordered nanopores, i.e., SBA-15 are extensively used as absorbent, biocatalytic support, and drug delivery candidate. Rios et al. [119] utilized poreexpanded mesoporous silica, i.e., SBA-15 to immobilize lipase from a recombinant C. antarctica by physical adsorption method. The resultant biocatalytic system showed greater activity and functional steadiness even after reusing for five successive batches. In addition, the biocatalyst SBA-15-LIPB was tested in ethyl hexanoate hydrolysis. Also, the immobilized biocatalyst catalyzed the esterification and hydrolysis reactions with high activity and stability. The hierarchically macro/mesoporous silica sphere immobilized catalase demonstrated high catalytic performance and appreciable recyclability as compared to its carrier-free counterpart [84]. In a recent study, Xiang et al. [161] fabricated a novel nanocomposite by amalgamating mesoporous silica SBA-15 material with chitosan using an ionic liquid as the linking agent and used as efficient carrier support for immobilizing porcine pancreas lipase. The catalytic properties such as stability, activity, and recyclability were substantially improved after enzyme immobilization to newly developed support. The immobilized lipase showed a superior pH tolerance and temperature stability indicating the inorganic-organic nanocomposite as a suitable candidate for enzyme immobilization. Of most recent, Shao et al. [130] immobilized laccase onto modified hollow mesoporous carbon spheres. The carrier-supported laccase displayed a noteworthy pH, storage and thermal stability, as well as good reusability. Further, it showed a high removal efficiency for two antibiotics namely, ciprofloxacin hydrochloride and tetracycline hydrochloride in the presence of redox mediator that indicates its potential in environmental remediation purposes. Burkholderia cepacia lipase adsorbed onto phenyl-modified ordered mesoporous silica showed potential efficiency as a nanocatalyst for the resolution of 1-phenyl ethanol. It led to a 50% conversion of 1-phenylethanol in only 25 min of incubation, which was almost 65-folds faster than that to its carrier-free enzyme counterpart. Moreover, it kept relatively constant activity up to 50 consecutive cycles that indicate its usefulness as an attractive biocatalyst in industrial exploitability [175]. In summary, various novel meso/nano-porous materials used for enzyme immobilization along with their improved biocatalytic properties, and applications are summarized in Table 2.
5.3. Carbon nanotubes as support carriers
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are an interesting type of new support materials that have attracted considerable research attention in recent years. Both single-walled and multi-walled carbon
M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23 15
nanotubes (MWCNTs) have evidenced as excellent immobilization support matrices owing to their ordered, nonporous structure, biocompatibility, large surface area, and exceptional chemical, thermal, mechanical, and electrical properties [150]. CNTs are easily surface modified that facilitate the formation of robust enzyme interactions with carrier supports [109]. In contrast to other materials, CNTs exhibit greater electrons transferring ability between the immobilized enzyme and substrate and therefore are widely pursued to immobilizing oxidoreductases for environmental detection and remediation purposes. Nevertheless, a wide variety of many other enzymes has also been insolubilized/immobilized on to CNTs for numerous applications [92]. For example, Ahmad and Khare, [2] reported the covalent immobilization of A. niger cellulase onto functionalized MWCNTs by carbodiimide linkage in the presence of N-hydroxysuccinimide. Under optimal conditions, the resulting nanobiocatalyst revealed 85% activity along with enhanced pH and temperature resistance. In contrast to the free
form of cellulase enzyme, the immobilized enzyme showed a 4- folds increased half-life at 70 C. The reusability of the enzyme preparation for ten times without losing significant activity indicates its potential for efficient hydrolysis of cellulose polymer. In order to retain enzyme stability at higher temperatures and in organic solvents for industrial applicability, Anwar and coworkers [5] scrutinized the use of high surface area SnO2 hollow nanotubes as carrier support for the covalent attachment of three different enzymes including lipase, horseradish peroxidase, and glucose oxidase. Notably, the hollow nanotubes-based support was found to be promising for all enzymes, where lipase displayed the utmost immobilization efficiency and yield of 89% and immobilization yield of 93%, respectively. As compared to free enzyme, the covalently attached lipase exhibited elevated thermal stability and a higher remaining activity even under unfavorable solvent conditions. Further, it showed a t1/2 of 4.5 h at 70 C along with retaining about 91% of its initial activity after repeated uses ten times. In

another study, laccase was covalently immobilized onto supermagnetically tunes, and c-aminopropyltriethoxysilane functionalized Halloysite nanotubes using glutaraldehyde as a cross-linker. The resulting developed nano-catalytic system showed an active recovery and loading capacity of 90.20% and 84.26 mg/g, respectively, combined with significantly enhanced storage and thermal stabilities. It also demonstrated a remarkably stable activity of 80.49% up to ninth repeated reusable cycle [69]. The chitosanhalloysite clay nanotube membranes adsorbed lipase revealed increased pH, and thermal stability and durable reusability for the lipids decomposition retaining over 70% and 90% of its original activity at pH of 9 and 80 C. Moreover, it preserved 85% of the initial catalytic performance after consecutively using for ten reaction batches indicating as a promising candidate in anti-biofouling applications [144]. Recently, Khan et al. [71] developed a high yielding procedure for the immobilization a-galactosidase of Aspergillus oryzae on polyaniline cobalt MWCNTs nanocomposite using glutaraldehyde as a cross-linker. In contrast to the native enzyme, the resulting nanocomposite-immobilized enzyme was found to be more stable against pH variations and elevated temperature. It also retained more than 90% of original activity after successively reusing for ten times indicating nanocomposite as a novel and convenient support for the immobilization of agalactosidase [71]. 5.4. Nanoparticles as support carriers
5.4.1. Magnetic nanoparticles In recent years, nanoparticles with diameters up to 30 nm have been widely investigated as noteworthy support materials for enzyme immobilization due to the fact that they provide a large surface area that results in higher enzyme loading and thereby elevated immobilization yield. Their capability to reduce diffusional limitations is an additional advantage of nanoparticles than many other inorganic materials. Magnetic nanoparticles (mNPs) are considered as attractive supporting matrices because of exceptional attributes such as minimum toxicity, high enzyme loading capacity, malleability to surface modification, and good repeatability in multiple cycles [177]. Fig. 3 illustrates a schematic preparation on mNPs, their formation process, and significant advantages. At present, magnetite and maghemite, in particular, are extensively used due to their non-toxicity, nanoscale size, abundant availability, stability, environmentally-friendliness, and facile recovery from the reaction mixture [29,117]. Generally, MNPs consist of a magnetic core surrounded by a polymer shell, which may constitute different materials such as acrylamide, cellulose, chitosan, silica, etc. depending on the enzymes application. The polymer shell materials should be biocompatible, eco-friendly, non-toxic, and exhibit low processing cost for commercial feasibility. Numerous procedures have been developed to fabricate MNPs, and their surfaces can be functionalized to increase the enzyme affinity with the
18 M .Bilal,H .M .N .Iqbal/Coordination Chem istry R eview s 388 (2019) 1– 23
M. Bilal, H.M.N. Iqbal / Coordination Chemistry Reviews 388 (2019) 1–23 19
nanoparticles [166,82]. In addition to high enzyme loading, immobilization of enzymes onto MNPs offers an easy approach to separate enzymes from the reaction media. In particular, covalent attachment diminishes enzyme leaching from the nanoparticlebased support [117,177].
The development of super-paramagnetic nanoparticles provides a large specific surface area, high binding efficiency, minimum mass transfer resistance, and rapid enzymes separation and reduced operating costs [55]. Since the particles in a superparamagnetic formulation do not exhibit a continuous magnetic property, therefore external magnetization would be useful for purifying a high-value product [168]. Recently, Miao and coworkers [94] synthesized superparamagnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles by chemical co-precipitation approach and surface functionalized with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane. This immobilization material was used as a support to attach lipase by means of glutaraldehyde as a cross-linker covalently. Notably, the obtained nanocomposite showed more than 70% conversion of fatty acid methyl ester after recycling the biocatalyst for five consecutive operations. Further, the immobilized lipases could be separated easily by an external magnetic field for its further cyclic utilization. In another study, soybean peroxidase was immobilized onto various novel silicacoated superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (Fig. 4) [37]. The resulting magnetic nanobiocatalysts showed potential efficiency for the degradation of an environmentally related dye pollutant malachite green. Further, the thermal steadiness and repeated use capability of the immobilized enzyme was also increased indicating its usefulness for wastewater treatment [37].
As compared to other immobilization techniques and supports, enzyme attachment onto magnetic carriers leads to increased substrate affinity and protects the resulting nanobiocatalysts against variations in pH and temperature. Similarly, the enzyme efficiently preserves its activity during a longer storage period. In addition, covalently immobilized magnetic nanobioconjugates also have extended reusable potential presumably due to the minimum enzyme leaching from the support. Papain enzyme was effectively immobilized onto biocompatible Fe3O4/SF nanoparticles by covalent linkages. The resulting immobilized bio-catalytic system demonstrated an elevated enzyme catalytic activity and wide working pH and thermal stability than that to the free form of the enzyme. It can easily be separated and recovered from the reaction media by the external magnetic field for repeated uses. After eight successive catalytic cycles, the immobilized papain retained 70% of its original activity, whereas the soluble enzyme completely lost its proteolytic activity. In addition, the immobilized enzyme also preserved 85% of preliminary activity after incubating for 28 days [138]. Cabrera et al. [23] developed a polyaniline-coated magnetic diatomaceous earth nanocomposite for the efficient immobilization of three different industrially important enzymes including b-galactosidase, invertase, and trypsin (Fig. 5). Characterization studies revealed that all the three nanobiocatalysts demonstrated superior catalytic performance and thermal stability in relation to their corresponding free forms. In addition, the easy recovery from enzymatic derivatives from the reactor using an external magnetic field make it a promising magnetic biocatalyst with potential industrial applications. Covalently immobilized lipase from Yarrowia lipolytica onto dithiocarbamate functionalized Fe3O4@C-NHCS2H core-shell nanoparticles exhibited superior biocatalytic performance and steadiness under harsh conditions of pH and temperature (Fig. 6). Further, it also showed high reusability for several cycles along with facile recovery owing to the magnetic property of the nano support [40]. Park et al. [105] conjugated b-galactosidase enzyme on MNPs solid core supports to develop recyclable biocatalysts using glutaraldehyde as a crosslinking agent (Fig. 7). Notwithstanding a reduced enzyme activity, immobilization led to enhanced temperature stability under the
harsh conditions. Moreover, the resulting bioconjugate catalyzed the complete hydrolysis of p-nitrophenyl b-D-glucoside until the three cycles and maintained a significant initial activity after successively reusing for ten rounds. Apart from the covalent coupling, immobilization of a-amylase onto naringin-modified MNPs through ionic interactions also showed promising catalytic performance [34]. Reusability results revealed that the immobilized enzyme presented profound activity even after recycling for successive ten reaction batches. Following immobilization, the shelf life was substantially enhanced, and the insolubilized enzyme preserved 60% of its original activity after six weeks of storage at 4 C. In contrary, magnetic immobilization can also display some drawbacks, for example, air, as well as these nanoparticles, may oxidize some Fe3O4 nanoparticles might aggregate because of the strong magnetic attractions between these that are a major hindrance for larger scale bioprocesses [48]. Various functionalized magnetic nanoparticles as support materials for enzyme immobilization along with their improved biocatalytic properties and applications are summarized in Table 4.
5.4.2. Non-magnetic nanoparticles Various inorganic materials and some semi-conductive materials with different physicochemical properties have been employed to generate nanoparticles with high sensitivity and specificity [132]. Among the materials, gold nanoparticles have attracted a growing researcher’s interest as very alluring candidates due to their outstanding biocompatibility, chemical activity, as well as, electrical and optical properties [176]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is also an intriguing support material for immobilizing a variety of enzymes owing to its relatively low manufacture cost, chemical stability, and high refractive index [73]. García-Morales et al. [46] carried out the immobilization of laccase enzymes from Pycnoporus sanguineus CS43 onto titania nanoparticles functionalized by 3- aminopropyltriethoxysilane and glutaraldehyde as a coupling and cross-linking agent, respectively. Immobilized biocatalyst displayed high resistance at acidic pH values of 2.0 and 3.0 with a half-life of 31.8 and 107.1 h. respectively. Similarly, the thermal stability was enhanced with a half-life of 45.7 and 3.7 h at 50 and 60 C, respectively. Additionally, the biocatalyst showed potential efficiency for the biotransformation and biodegradation of emerging contaminants such as acetaminophen (more than 90% after two h) and diclofenac (68% after 8 h). The covalent attachment of cellulase enzyme onto cross-linked styrene/maleic anhydride copolymer nanoparticles showed an elevated pH tolerance compared to a free form of the enzyme and able to preserve 80% of its original activity at an alkaline pH of 8.0. It also presented outstanding reusability in catalyzing the carboxymethylcellulose sodium salt hydrolysis with preservation of about 100% catalytic activity after repeatedly using for six times [156]. ZnO nanoparticles attached protease enzyme exhibited long-term storage and thermal steadiness along with excellent tolerance to extreme pH values [35]. Hooda and Archita [56] synthesized a novel chitosan/coconut fiber/zinc oxide nanoparticles hybrid support to coimmobilize polyamine oxidase and diamine oxidase (Fig. 8). The obtained immobilized enzymes revealed excellent catalytic efficacy, thermal (more than 50% of its initial activity at 40 C), storage (half-life of 40 days) and working stabilities (retained more than 90% activity after 20 cycles. Finally, the newly developed nanobioconjugate showed reliable, comparable, and reproducible results for polyamine determination in some locally cultivated vegetables and fruits. In another study, co-immobilization of purified chitinase and N-acetyl b-glucosaminidase on newly synthesized polyurethane/zinc oxide nanoparticles biocomposite demonstrated improved storage and thermal stabilities and was recyclable in 10 successive reaction times without loss of any significant catalytic activity [113]. 6. Concluding remarks and perspectives
Recent advances in the development of a wealth of diverse nanostructured support materials and immobilization approaches have enabled precise immobilization of biocatalysts, and therefore, has been a subject of pronounced interest in current years to flourishing the nanobiocatalysts-mediated industrial bioprocesses. Specifically, functionalized nanomaterials intensely affect the intrinsic mechanical properties and provide high biocompatibility and unique nano-environments surrounding the enzyme for upgrading enzyme catalytic activity and stability and reaction efficiencies. Additionally, immobilization of enzyme on nanocarrier constructs can greatly increase the durability and robustness of the enzymes for its repeated use, which might diminish the overall cost of the bio-catalytic processes. However, to date, there are lacking comprehensive reports systematically inspecting the interactions between the nanocarrier properties and the biocatalysts. Therefore, increasing knowledge and fundamental understanding of the physicochemical properties of nanocarriers and features of the biocatalysts (structure and mechanism of action), as well as, and interfacial interactions related to the nanocarrier-enzyme system are significantly indispensable to develop sustainable, innovative bioprocesses. In spite of the great success, several challenges still exist that need to be overcome for real-time applications at industrial scale. First, the cost associated with enzyme biosynthesis/preparation, nanostructured carrier creation, and immobilization is one of the main obstacles for scale-up applications. However, most of the nanomaterials are still manufacturing at the laboratory scale. Secondly, most of the nanobiocatalysts developed only exhibit proof-of-concept realization, and a limited number of nanocarriers-immobilized biocatalysts have been successfully operated for up to 10–15 consecutive repeated batches. Therefore, catalytic activity, durability, mechanical steadiness, and leaching of enzyme should be assessed for their continuous maneuver. With the integrated struggles from biochemists, nanobiotechnologists, bioprocess engineers and materials scientists, these advanced multifunctional nanostructured carriers immobilized biocatalysts could be successfully industrialized in the coming few years.
